II. Purpose of Addendum
The facility has requested the addition of a Residential Treatment Program. The
Residential Treatment Program will occupy fourteen single rooms on the 3rd Floor of
the building. Ten rooms on the second floor of the facility will continue to be utilized
as double occupancy rooms for short term programs. Based on these changes, the
capacity of the short term programs will be 20 and the capacity of the Residential
Treatment Program will be 14. The total capacity is 34.
III. Methodology
02/21/2006- Received a written proposal from the Chief Administrator to add a
Residential Treatment component to Wolverine Center.
03/03/2006- Onsite inspection of the facility. The rooms identified for the Residential
Treatment Program were previously utilized for the short term program. The
Environmental and Fire Safety Inspections are current.
03/06/2006- Received a revised Program Statement for Wolverine Center and a
revised Child Caring Institution Application.
03/20/2006- Modify terms to 20 short term male residents, ages 6-17, and 14 male
residential treatment residents, ages 12-17. Decrease total capacity to 34.
IV. Description of Findings and Conclusions
Wolverine Human Services is an established nonprofit Child Care Organization.
Wolverine Center has been licensed since January 1988. The facility has previously
provided short term care for abused and neglected males and low security
adjudicated delinquents. The facility had eliminated the delinquent program for a
short period of time, but contracted with a new funding source to continue the
program.
The facility has requested to add a Residential Treatment component to the
program. The addition of the program will allow the facility to have single rooms for
residents who have a history of sexually acting out either prior to or during
placement.
The facility has the space to accommodate the Residential Treatment Program. The
rooms to be used for the new program were previously utilized for the short term
program. The Environmental and Fire Safety Inspections are current. The facility is
aware of the need to programmatically and physically separate the short term
programs that house adjudicated delinquents (non-status offenders) and
abuse/neglect wards. This is a Federal Title IV-E requirement. Both short term
programs will be on the second floor. They will occupy different sides of the Resident
Hall. A Fire Door separates the two sides. They will continue to have separate
meals and recreation activities. Separate Education Programs will continue at the
onsite self contained classrooms.
2

The Residential Treatment Program will be housed on the 3rd Floor. Fourteen single
beds will be used for this program. The Program will serve youth from 12-17 years of
age. The addition of the program will allow the facility to have single rooms for
residents who have a history of sexually acting out either prior to or during
placement.
Meals, recreational activities, and educational classes for residents in the
Residential Treatment Program will be separate from the residents in the short term
programs. The staffing ratio for the Residential Treatment Program will be 1:7 during
waking hours and 1:12 during sleeping hours. Residents will be provided group,
individual, and family counseling. The facility plans to require additional training for
staff persons assigned to the Residential Treatment Program.
V. Recommendation
Based on a revised Program Statement, building inspection, and current Fire and
Environmental Inspections, it is recommended that the request to add a 14 bed
residential program is approved The license capacity is decreased to 34 to
accommodate 20 short term residents, ages 6-17, and 14 Residential Treatment
residents, ages 12-17.
